plc.project

Class Lexer

  • java.lang.Object
    • plc.project.Lexer

  • public final class Lexer
extends java.lang.Object
    The lexer works through three main functions: - lex(), which repeatedly calls lexToken() and skips whitespace - lexToken(), which lexes the next token - Lexer.CharStream, which manages the state of the lexer and literals If the lexer fails to parse something (such as an unterminated string) you should throw a ParseException with an index at the character which is invalid or missing. The peek(String...) and match(String...) functions are helpers you need to use, they will make the implementation a lot easier.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Lexer.CharStream
      A helper class maintaining the input string, current index of the char stream, and the current length of the token being matched.

    • Method Detail

      • lex

        public java.util.List<Token> lex()
        Repeatedly lexes the input using lexToken(), also skipping over whitespace where appropriate.

      • lexToken

        public Token lexToken()
        This method determines the type of the next token, delegating to the appropriate lex method. As such, it is best for this method to not change the state of the char stream (thus, use peek not match). The next character should start a valid token since whitespace is handled by lex()

      • lexIdentifier

        public Token lexIdentifier()

      • lexNumber

        public Token lexNumber()

      • lexCharacter

        public Token lexCharacter()

      • lexString

        public Token lexString()

      • lexEscape

        public void lexEscape()

      • lexOperator

        public Token lexOperator()

      • peek

        public boolean peek(java.lang.String... patterns)
        Returns true if the next sequence of characters match the given patterns, which should be a regex. For example, peek("a", "b", "c") would return true if the next characters are 'a', 'b', 'c'.

      • match

        public boolean match(java.lang.String... patterns)
        Returns true in the same way as peek(String...), but also advances the character stream past all matched characters if peek returns true. Hint - it's easiest to have this method simply call peek.
